citation.article-title: Bordetella petrii sp. nov., isolated from an anaerobic bioreactor, and emended description of the genus Bordetella.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Bordetella pertussis sp. nov.
Bordetella pertussis (pe'trii. N.L. gen. n. petrii of Petri, named in honour of R. J. Petri, an early German microbiologist who developed the Petri-dish (Petri, 1887))
B. petrii was isolated from an anaerobic, dechlorinating mixed culture which had been enriched from river sediment (Saale near Jena, Germany).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, non-motile and rod-shaped to circular.
Cells are 0.4-0.7 μm wide to 1.0-2.8 μmin length.
Cells possess fimbriae of different diameters.
Colonies are of white-creamy colour and differ in size.
Growth occurs under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions.
Anaerobic growth is non-fermentative, possibly due to denitrification or to selenate reduction to elemental selenium.
Some biochemical characteristics are described in the text and in Table 2.
The major respiratory isoprenoid quinone is Q-8.
Strain Se-1111RT is designated the type strain (=DSM 12804T=CCUG 43448T).
